I disagree. Most commenters DO have respect for the runners (less so for the organizers). Overall there is immense sympathy for people who have trained hard for months & years. The strong reactions involve the decision not to postpone the event.

Angiefern points out that the race doesn't go through MOST of the affected areas. That qualifier "most " is a harsh indictment. Even if the race avoided ALL affected areas it would be a distasteful, disgraceful decision.

As for costs: There is certainly going to be a police presence to control crowds & traffic. Every one of those officers should be helping the rescue effort or catching some rest. Today I've watched dozens of stricken New Yorkers in Staten Island & Breezy Point & Long Beach begging, sobbing, imploring for help, for SOMEONE to show up. By Sunday the problems will be marginally alleviated & the despair intensified. It is a bitter mockery for them to know that first responders are lining a race route.

Postpone the race for a week. Free up hotels & flights & officers needed by those in desperate straights. Then hold a truly celebratory race, free of divisive controversy, a week late. Yes there will be inconvenience for those who can't reschedule, just as there is for those who can't run this Sunday.

There is no longer a perfect solution that spares all participants from difficulty, but a brief postponement will show that there is respect, resources & priorities allocated by the city to those who need it most right now.

I am a Family Medicine senior resident. When I asked my ICU attending why we were doing yet another procedure on a 98 year old, non-verbal, non-responsive, contracted patient, with a feeding tube and a rectal tube, he replied, "It's better than practicing on dogs." So go ahead, Dr. ICU, practice your expensive procedures on the dying elderly. You will save one person once in awhile with these procedures you have spent years perfecting. But the rest of the time, Medicare dollars are going down the drain to prolong the last few months of life, without care for dignity or pain, and you are congratulating yourself on what a valuable and amazing doctor you are.

Meanwhile, I will go on... catching developmental delays in babies and toddlers, helping new mothers with sick infants, talking to families about new symptoms of dementia, discussing cancer diagnoses with patients who didn't understand what the specialist told them, helping young people with contraception choices, examining rashes, knowing my patients throughout their lives. Living through their bad times and good times.

You may stave off death, and bully for you, but I help people live life. You are concerned that your amazing paycheck is threatened by changes in the system, like a dog with a bone. Meanwhile, I get to sleep well at night, knowing I'm working long hours and making these sacrifices for the love of humanity and not for the money. Now who is more valuable?

This country needs courageous leadership on climate change. That's leadership, not bowing to corporate fossil fuel pressure, as Obama has mostly done in the past four years. Congratulations to Bloomberg for spelling it out publicly... finally. (And kudos to Cuomo for being the *first* to utter the truth after the storm, something Christie wouldn't do, and Bloomberg didn't do initially.) Creating pedestrian areas in Manhattan an putting pots in them with plants is not an environmental policy, Mr. Mayor. But perhaps a public role on this issue would be one way of making up for the lost time of your three terms.
And may Obama find it in himself to lead the nation on this issue, not just wait for disaster to pile on disaster. Leadership is a skill to hone. It means using the public role of the presidency to galvanize people in masses to understand the facts behind threats and fighting for policies that will benefit the many, not just those at the top of the corporate heap.

@Mitra,
Fair enough. The points you make are valid. But just so we don't keep talking past each other, let me state clearly that my problem was purely with the denigration of manual labor. That lower caste people can and do rise (which I agree with) is irrelevant to that point. Our society will not advance as long as we continue to treat certain occupations as so beyond the pale that no self-respecting person would be caught touching it with a mile-long pole. If my years of living in the West have taught me anything, it is that a society that respects all kinds of work, and all kinds of workers, is a better society and one that has the potential to keep advancing. Otherwise work takes a back seat to status-jockeying, which I see abundant evidence of in India.

Billionaire *Wealth* as a share of GDP is a weird measure, and likely to be a bit misleading for most readers. Wealth is a stock (total income of various kinds plus other assets minus spending over one's lifetime). GDP is the country's income over a year. I suspect that a lot of readers will interpret the 22% wealth to GDP ratio as meaning that 45 odd individuals earn 22% of the country's income. In reality, the number will be much smaller.
